study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether white noise could reduce pain during endotracheal suctioning in mechanically ventilated neonates.
results_summary: The study found that white noise had little or no effect on pain scores (PIPP), heart rate, or oxygen saturation during endotracheal suctioning compared to no intervention. The evidence was based on a single study with low certainty.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates who were mechanically ventilated and required endotracheal suctioning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether white noise influenced head sway in individuals with vestibular disorders during sensory integration tasks.
results_summary: The study found that sound (including white noise) was not a significant predictor of head sway in the protocol used, indicating no measurable effect on vestibular rehabilitation outcomes.
population_specificity: Thirty participants with vestibular dysfunction and 21 age-matched controls.
effective_dosage: Rhythmic white noise (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Startle Adjuvant Rehabilitation Therapy (START), which includes 105-dB white noise GO cues, improves aphasia, apraxia of speech, and quality of life in individuals with chronic stroke.
results_summary: START improved performance on some speech and comprehension tasks in individuals with moderate/severe aphasia and enhanced mood and perceived communication recovery by Day 5, while controls saw no changes. Effects were more pronounced in moderate/severe cases, though small effect sizes and variability were noted.
population_specificity: Individuals with poststroke aphasia, apraxia of speech, or both (42 participants).
effective_dosage: 105-dB white noise GO cues during one third of trials in three 1-hour sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a responsive parenting intervention, including white noise as a soothing strategy, on maternal responses to infant crying.
results_summary: The study found that mothers in the responsive parenting intervention were significantly more likely to use white noise to soothe their infants at 8 and 16 weeks compared to controls, with odds ratios of 4.9 and 4.8, respectively. The intervention also increased the use of other non-food soothing strategies.
population_specificity: Primiparous Black mothers and their infants.
study_duration: Home visits at 3 and 8 weeks postpartum, with follow-up assessments at 8 and 16 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the sleep-inducing effects of various auditory stimuli, including white noise, for individuals with or without insomnia who struggle to fall asleep.
results_summary: The study reviewed experiments on auditory stimuli, including white noise, and suggested that such methods may help induce sleep, though clinical methods like drugs or cognitive behavioral therapy remain dominant.
population_specificity: Individuals with or without insomnia who have difficulty falling asleep.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether listening to white noise could reduce cannulation pain in hemodialysis patients compared to music.
results_summary: The study found that white noise had a minimal effect on reducing cannulation pain, with a median change in pain score of -0.3 mm, significantly less effective than music (-2.7 mm). The adjusted difference in pain scores between music and white noise was -12% in favor of music.
population_specificity: 121 hemodialysis patients who reported pain during cannulation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (white noise was used as a control during the cannulation procedure).
study_duration: Duration of the cannulation procedure (exact time not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the spatial location of white noise affects its ability to mask simulated tinnitus.
results_summary: White noise presented from a distant speaker and binaurally recorded noise localized outside the head masked simulated tinnitus more effectively (71.1% and 77.1% of measurements, respectively) at lower intensities compared to noise beside the ear or inside-head noise. Spatial information of the masking noise may reduce tinnitus perception.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers with simulated 4 kHz tinnitus in the right ear.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intensity adjusted for masking effect).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the scientific literature to determine the effectiveness of white noise and other auditory stimulation types on sleep outcomes in adults.
results_summary: The study found that 33% of white noise studies reported positive findings in improving sleep outcomes, but overall, there was no strong evidence to support its use. No adverse effects were reported with short-term application.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how contralateral white noise masking affects the amplitude and latency of the V wave in ABR measurements and assess its necessity in unilateral sensorineural hearing loss.
results_summary: The study found that contralateral white noise masking at 80 dB did not significantly alter the amplitude or latency of the V wave in normal hearing individuals. However, it was necessary for accurate ABR measurements in severe or profound unilateral sensorineural hearing loss at specific frequencies and intensities.
population_specificity: Adults with normal hearing (Experiment 1) and individuals with severe/profound unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (Experiment 2).
effective_dosage: Masking intensities ranged from 0 to 80 dB.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of sensory interventions, including environmental white noise, on the quality of life of residents in long-term care settings.
results_summary: The study identified environmental white noise as one of 16 categories of sensory interventions but did not provide specific findings on its efficacy or outcomes. The review included 52 articles, but details on white noise's effects were not highlighted.
population_specificity: Residents in long-term care settings with diminishing senses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether directional sound (including static white noise) improves balance in children with bilateral cochleovestibular loss using cochlear implants.
results_summary: Balance improved slightly but significantly when children had access to sound through cochlear implants, including static white noise, but no additional benefit was observed with directional sounds. Typically developing children performed worse with directional sound compared to static white noise.
population_specificity: Children with sensorineural hearing loss and bilateral vestibular loss (SNHL-BVL) using bilateral cochlear implants, compared to typically developing children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review studies on the effects of continuous white noise or similar broadband noise on sleep outcomes, including sleep onset latency, fragmentation, quality, and duration.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with some evidence suggesting white noise improves sleep and other evidence indicating it may disrupt sleep; the overall quality of evidence was very low, contradicting its widespread use as a sleep aid.
population_specificity: Not specified (systematic review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether white noise, compared to music therapy and no sound, could reduce pain and anxiety during haemodialysis access cannulation.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for white noise, but the study design suggests it was used as a control condition to compare against music therapy and no sound for pain and anxiety management during cannulation.
population_specificity: Haemodialysis patients (n=120) across five facilities.
effective_dosage: Not specified (white noise was played 8 minutes prior to cannulation and continued after starting haemodialysis).
study_duration: One week per condition (white noise, music, no sound).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether white noise stimulation via cochlear implantation could improve tinnitus symptoms in adults with single-sided deafness.
results_summary: White noise stimulation for one month significantly improved Tinnitus Handicap Inventory scores, though other measures remained unchanged. After switching to standard CI stimulation, 92% of patients reported significant tinnitus improvement, with 54% experiencing over 40% improvement.
population_specificity: Adults with single-sided deafness and incapacitating tinnitus (THI >58).
effective_dosage: Not specified (white noise delivered via cochlear implant).
study_duration: 1 month of white noise stimulation, followed by standard CI stimulation for 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure listening effort using a dual-task paradigm involving working memory and speech perception under white noise conditions at different signal-to-noise ratios.
results_summary: The study found that white noise significantly influenced speech perception tasks (logatomes and meaningless sentences) in both ears, but listening effort and working memory tasks showed significant differences only in the right ear. The proposed paradigm was sensitive for quantifying auditory effort.
population_specificity: 10 young adults (18-30 years) with normal hearing and similar socio-cultural backgrounds.
effective_dosage: Signal-to-noise ratios of +5 and -5dB with white noise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of white noise in tinnitus retraining therapy and whether the claimed optimal stimulation is achievable given influencing factors.
results_summary: The study found that achieving optimal white noise perception is unlikely due to factors like emitted noise spectrum, ear canal resonance, and hearing sensitivity, potentially explaining the long habituation periods required. It suggests developing devices to counter these factors.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing tinnitus retraining therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of the 4S soothing techniques (including white noise) on infants' self-regulation behaviors related to sleeping, crying, and feeding.
results_summary: The study found that infants in the intervention group (taught 4S techniques) had statistically significant reductions in night waking, daily feeding frequency, and crying duration, as well as increased sleep duration in weeks 7 and 11 compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Mother-infant dyads (21 in intervention group, 21 in control group) during the first 23 weeks postpartum.
effective_dosage: Not specified (white noise was part of a 90-minute training program).
study_duration: Follow-ups at weeks 3, 7, 11, and 23 after birth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a modeling framework using white noise stimulation to improve the performance of bionic retinal implants by better understanding and selectively activating retinal ganglion cells.
results_summary: The study proposed a white noise-based modeling framework to enhance electrical stimulation of retinal ganglion cells, potentially enabling selective activation for improved bionic retinal implants. The approach builds on historical white noise methods and recent adaptations for retinal stimulation.
population_specificity: Individuals with degenerative retinal diseases (e.g., retinitis pigmentosa, macular degeneration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate auditory hallucinatory experiences in psychiatric patients, a religious group, and a control group using the White Christmas Test to assess vivid imagery hearing under white noise conditions.
results_summary: Patients showed greater attributional bias and hallucinatory experiences compared to religious and control groups, while the control group exhibited higher negative schizotypy than the religious group, suggesting religious practices might mitigate negative schizotypy effects.
population_specificity: Psychiatric patients, evangelical Christians, and a non-religious, non-psychiatric control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and patient preference of different colored sound generators (white, red, and pink noise) in Tinnitus Retraining Therapy (TRT).
results_summary: Both white noise and multi-color sound generators significantly improved tinnitus discomfort after 3 and 6 months, with no significant difference between groups. Two-thirds of patients preferred white noise, while the rest chose red noise; no one selected pink noise.
population_specificity: 20 patients with tinnitus and normal hearing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of non-pharmacological interventions, including white noise, in improving sleep quality among post-cardiac surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that white noise, along with other interventions like earplugs and relaxation techniques, significantly improved sleep quality scores in post-cardiac surgery patients. However, no high-quality studies (as per Jadad scoring) were identified.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent cardiac surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of therapeutic suggestions under general anesthesia to white noise (as an attention control) in improving postoperative outcomes like pain, mental distress, medication use, and recovery.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects of therapeutic suggestions compared to white noise on pain intensity or mental distress but observed small positive effects on medication use and recovery.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing surgery or medical procedures under general anesthesia.
study_duration: Duration of general anesthesia (not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the diagnostic quality and utility of synthetic MR imaging versus conventional MR imaging for routine neuroimaging.
results_summary: Synthetic MR imaging quality was noninferior to conventional imaging for most contrasts, though synthetic T2 FLAIR had more artifacts, which were recognizable and did not mimic pathology.
population_specificity: 109 subjects (mean age 53.0 ± 18.5 years, range 19-89) with neuroimaging indications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether nocebo suggestions influenced startle responses and pain perception, using white noise to elicit startle responses.
results_summary: The study found that nocebo suggestions increased pain reports and startle responses, with increased startle significantly associated with the nocebo hyperalgesic effect. White noise was effectively used to measure startle responses but its direct effects were not the primary focus.
population_specificity: Participants were randomized into placebo, natural history, or nocebo groups; specific demographics not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the accuracy and repeatability of extended bandwidth measurements of white noise in ear canals at different insertion depths using narrowband and wideband signal analysis.
results_summary: Test-retest differences were within ±2 dB for typical frequency bandwidths at clinically relevant insertion depths, with the 28 mm insertion depth being the best predictor of ear canal levels at 30 mm. Signal analysis bandwidth did not affect accuracy or repeatability.
population_specificity: Fourteen female adults with normal hearing and middle-ear function.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether education on the use of sleep-enhancing tools, including white noise, could improve health outcomes such as fatigue and sleep-related symptoms in hospitalized patients.
results_summary: Participants who received education on sleep-enhancing tools, including white noise, showed a significant reduction in fatigue scores compared to controls. Other sleep-related domains showed trends toward improvement, though not statistically significant, and no differences were found in opioid use or length of stay.
population_specificity: 120 adults admitted to a non-intensive care unit cardiac-monitored floor.
effective_dosage: Not specified (white noise machine provided, but details on settings or duration of use not mentioned).

study_goal: The study aimed to compare the intrinsic image quality of synthesized 2D c-view and 2D FFDM images in terms of resolution, contrast, and noise.
results_summary: The study found that FFDM images scored higher than c-view in ACR-defined criteria, with c-view failing to meet minimum requirements in many cases. C-view showed better visualization of medium and large microcalcifications but poorer resolution and noise properties compared to FFDM.
population_specificity: Phantoms (ACR mammography accreditation phantom and a 3D printed anthropomorphic breast phantom)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether music (including white noise as a comparator) improves recovery after surgical procedures by reducing pain, anxiety, and analgesia use.
results_summary: White noise was used as a comparator in some trials, but the study primarily focused on music's effects. Music showed significant benefits in reducing postoperative pain, anxiety, and analgesia use, while white noise's specific efficacy was not highlighted.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing surgical procedures (excluding central nervous system or head and neck surgeries).
study_duration: Varied by study (not specified for white noise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reducing the intensity of the unconditional stimulus (UCS, 100dB white noise) could diminish fear renewal across different contexts.
results_summary: The study found that UCS deflation (gradual reduction in white noise intensity) led to a sustained reduction in subjective cost ratings of the UCS, even after a context change, suggesting it may reduce fear renewal. However, UCS expectancy still increased after the context switch, indicating partial efficacy.
population_specificity: Healthy students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of anger rumination, reappraisal, and alcohol intoxication on intimate partner aggression (IPA) using an analogue aggression task involving white noise blasts.
results_summary: The study found that alcohol intoxication increased provoked IPA, while higher trait reappraisal reduced unprovoked IPA in the alcohol and rumination group. Higher trait rumination was linked to greater provoked IPA in the alcohol and rumination group and the placebo and uninstructed group.
population_specificity: 69 couples (total N = 138) recruited from a large Midwestern university.

study_goal: The researchers investigated whether pathological gamblers and controls differed in aversive classical conditioning using white noise as an aversive stimulus.
results_summary: The study found no group differences in habituation or acquisition phases, but pathological gamblers showed diminished aversive conditioning compared to controls during extinction. White noise was ineffective in forming aversive associations for pathological gamblers.
population_specificity: 20 pathological gamblers and 20 control participants.
effective_dosage: 100-dB burst of white noise paired with a tone stimulus.
study_duration: Not specified (phases included habituation, acquisition, and extinction).

study_goal: To compare the effect of suppression/reduction of otoacoustic emissions and their amplitude relative to lateral dominance in normal-hearing adults.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences between right and left ear results regarding asymmetry in otoacoustic emissions or the presence of suppression/reduction, indicating no lateral dominance in the study population.
population_specificity: 75 normal-hearing adults.
effective_dosage: White noise was used as contralateral stimulation at 60 dB SPL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the respiratory effects of white noise and classical Turkish music on schizophrenia patients versus healthy controls.
results_summary: Schizophrenia patients had higher respiration rates during white noise exposure compared to controls, but no significant differences in respiration depth. White noise did not evoke significant respiratory changes in patients during stimulation periods.
population_specificity: 46 individuals, including schizophrenia patients and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of white noise, fractal tones, and amplification in hearing aids on relaxation, tinnitus annoyance, handicap, and reaction.
results_summary: White noise reduced tinnitus annoyance for some participants, but only two opted for noise-only programs in the field trial. Most preferred fractal tones, which also improved relaxation and tinnitus-related measures over 6 months.
population_specificity: Fourteen hearing-impaired adults with subjective tinnitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of electrical stochastic noise stimulation (Bioelectrical Signal Therapy) on hard-to-heal wounds.
results_summary: Four patients (five ulcers) achieved complete closure, three patients showed reduced ulcer size with epithelialisation, one patient showed no improvement, and one discontinued due to skin irritation. The overall mean closure rate was 82.5%.
population_specificity: Nine patients (three males, six females) with hard-to-heal ulcers (duration: 18 months to 20 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a behavioral intervention involving white noise, among other techniques, could reduce crying in newborns when delivered via videotape.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in crying or sleeping durations between infants exposed to the intervention (including white noise) and the control group, indicating the intervention was not efficacious.
population_specificity: Mothers and their healthy, full-term newborns recruited from a postpartum unit.
study_duration: Assessed at 1st, 4th, 6th, 8th, and 12th weeks of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether implicit memory formation occurs in children during routine anesthesia when exposed to white noise or a sheep sound.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that exposure to a sheep sound during anesthesia was associated with postoperative recognition of a degraded sheep sound, suggesting no implicit memory formation. The results indicated no significant difference in recognition times between the white noise and sheep sound groups.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-12 years undergoing general anesthesia.
effective_dosage: Continuous exposure through headphones during anesthesia (specific decibel level or frequency not provided).
study_duration: Duration of anesthesia (not explicitly stated, but implied to be the length of the surgical procedure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of whole coffee fruit concentrate powder (WCFC) on blood levels of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) compared to other extracts and controls.
results_summary: WCFC increased plasma BDNF levels by 143% compared to baseline, significantly outperforming other tested extracts (31% increase). The results suggest WCFC may modulate BDNF-dependent health conditions, though larger studies are needed.
population_specificity: Fasted subjects (n=10 per group).
study_duration: Single-dose study with measurements up to 120 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers examined whether white noise exposure elicited different startle reflex and cortisol responses in heroin-dependent patients (on DAM or methadone) compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: Both heroin-dependent groups showed significantly smaller startle responses to white noise than healthy controls. DAM-maintained patients had significantly lower cortisol levels during the experiment compared to methadone-maintained patients and controls.
population_specificity: 57 participants (19 DAM-maintained heroin-dependent patients, 19 methadone-maintained heroin-dependent patients, 19 healthy controls), matched for age, sex, and smoking status.
effective_dosage: 24 bursts of white noise (specific intensity/frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Single experimental session (timing not specified beyond pre/post cortisol measurements).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of whole-body vibration (WBV) compared to conventional physical therapy for treating knee osteoarthritis (KOA) grade II and III.
results_summary: Both WBV and physical therapy improved patient status, with no significant differences in most outcomes. WBV showed non-inferiority to physical therapy, with some functional improvements, though conventional therapy had slightly better average improvement in general health status.
population_specificity: Patients with primary knee osteoarthritis (Gonarthrosis) grade II or III.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining whole-body vibration (WBV) with exercise therapy enhances motor cortical excitability, quadriceps strength, and functional abilities in athletes recovering from ACL reconstruction compared to exercise therapy alone.
results_summary: The study found that WBV plus exercise therapy significantly increased motor cortex excitability (measured by decreased AMT) compared to exercise therapy alone, but both groups showed similar improvements in quadriceps strength and daily functional abilities, suggesting the primary benefits may stem from exercise therapy.
population_specificity: Athletes recovering from anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions (3 sessions per week for 4 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV), either alone or combined with other therapies, on motor function in children with cerebral palsy compared to traditional physical therapy or no intervention.
results_summary: WBV significantly improved walking speed, Timed "Up & Go" Test performance, gross motor function, and postural stability in children with cerebral palsy, with no intolerable adverse effects reported. However, the certainty of the evidence was rated as very low or low.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy, particularly those with spastic cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effects of a single whole-body vibration session on mobility and postural control in community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: Participants who underwent whole-body vibration showed significant improvements in mobility compared to the placebo group, but no significant differences were observed in postural control. The study suggests that additional sessions may be needed for postural control benefits.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults
effective_dosage: Vibration amplitude of 2 mm and frequency of 40 Hz

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of high-intensity interval aerobic exercise (HIIAE) alone versus HIIAE combined with whole-body vibration (WBV) on molecular and neurocognitive indices in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: HIIAE+WBV improved accuracy rates, reaction times, ERP P3 amplitudes, and levels of osteocalcin, BDNF, and irisin more than HIIAE alone, suggesting acute benefits for bone and brain health. However, no significant correlations were found between the molecular and neurocognitive changes induced by the interventions.
population_specificity: Sedentary, healthy postmenopausal women (n=63).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an 8-week Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) exercise program on cardiorespiratory fitness, muscular strength, and body composition in young women with overweight and obesity.
results_summary: The WBV exercise group showed significant improvements in cardiorespiratory fitness (VO2peak), muscular strength, and reductions in body weight, BMI, body fat, and waist circumference compared to the control group. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Inactive young women with overweight and obesity (age: 30.2 ± 8.0 years, BMI: 25.7 ± 1.9 kg/m2).
effective_dosage: 3 sessions/week, 60 minutes/session (static and dynamic exercises on a vibration platform).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whole-body vibration (WBV) combined with home-based exercise (HBE), physical therapy modalities (PTM), or both on pain, physical performance, and functional status in knee osteoarthritis patients.
results_summary: WBV combined with PTM and HBE showed statistically and clinically significant improvements in pain, functional status, and physical performance. WBV with HBE alone improved only physical performance, while PTM with HBE showed no significant improvements.
population_specificity: 65 patients (3 males, 62 females; mean age 56.0±6.3 years) with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of high-frequency, low-magnitude whole-body vibration therapy on bone health, quality of life, pain, and balance in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant improvements in bone mineral density, bone turnover markers, pain, or quality of life after three months of WBV therapy. However, balance improved significantly across all groups, including the control group.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 45-65 years.
effective_dosage: High-frequency, low-magnitude WBV (specific parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of supervised exercise therapy alone versus combined with Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) in reducing pain and improving function in end-stage knee osteoarthritis patients awaiting total knee replacement.
results_summary: The study found that both exercise and exercise + WBV significantly reduced knee pain, with the WBV group showing greater reductions. WBV also led to significant improvements in functional outcomes (KOOS subscales) and knee range of motion, exceeding minimal clinically important differences and detectable change thresholds in some measures.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage knee osteoarthritis awaiting total knee replacement (n=555).
effective_dosage: Not specified (8-week intervention with strength and flexibility exercises, WBV details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the quality and extent of benefits of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) therapy in the elderly, focusing on cardiovascular hemodynamics, neuromuscular stability, and sarcopenia.
results_summary: WBV showed cardiovascular benefits like increased skin blood flow and improved endothelial function, mixed results on arterial stiffness, and no significant impact on blood pressure. It demonstrated significant improvements in muscle strength, functionality, and pain reduction in sarcopenia and osteoarthritis, with mixed results in stroke patients but benefits in Parkinson's disease.
population_specificity: Persons aged 50 and older, including those with osteoarthritis, Parkinson's disease, and stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of Whole-Body Vibration Without Visual Feedback (VFDWBV) on postural steadiness in unilateral traumatic trans-femoral amputees.
results_summary: The study found that VFDWBV significantly improved prosthetic leg stability, stability limit, and sway index (m-CTSIB) compared to standard WBV and conservative treatment. The VFDWBV group showed more significant postural steadiness improvements than the other groups.
population_specificity: Unilateral traumatic trans-femoral amputees aged 40-55 years.
effective_dosage: 30 Hz frequency, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the effects of 4 weeks of trunk training with whole-body vibrations on components of lumbar motor control.
results_summary: Whole-body vibration training significantly reduced lumbar spine motion angle in anterior pelvic tilt and ball-catching tasks but increased it in backward rocking. It enhanced control of decreasing lumbar motion but did not improve all components of lumbar motor control.
population_specificity: 24 healthy university students (12 males and 12 females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) on cognitive function and analyze the possible mechanisms underlying these effects.
results_summary: Short-term low-frequency WBV may positively impact cognitive function, enhancing learning and memory, while long-term exposure may lead to cognitive decline due to chronic stress on nerve tissue. The effects depend on vibration frequency and duration, with mechanisms involving neuroinflammation, oxidative stress, synaptic plasticity, and neurotransmitter changes.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review).
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency and amplitude mentioned as factors, but exact dosages not provided).
study_duration: Not specified (short-term vs. long-term effects discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whole-body vibration at 40 Hz could induce gamma oscillations and improve cognitive function in aged male rats.
results_summary: Whole-body vibration at 40 Hz, but not 20 Hz or 80 Hz, elicited cortical gamma oscillations and significantly improved cognitive function in aged male rats after 8 weeks of treatment. The benefits were linked to reduced neuronal apoptosis in the hippocampal CA1 region via regulation of neuron-astrocyte synaptic connections.
population_specificity: Aged male rats
effective_dosage: 40 Hz vibration (specific amplitude and frequency details not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate cortical activation patterns in the primary somatosensory cortex (S1) and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) during Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) and its subsequent effects on cognitive performance.
results_summary: The study found decreased cortical activation during WBV, particularly in the left DLPFC, but increased activation during a cognitive task (CWIT) and improved cognitive performance after WBV, especially at 12 Hz and 24 Hz frequencies. These results suggest WBV may enhance cognitive readiness.
population_specificity: 24 young adults (21.50 ± 1.59 years, 11 female).
effective_dosage: Frequencies of 12 Hz and 24 Hz, with postures of sitting or standing on a side-alternating vibration plate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) with Simvastatin (SIM) improves titanium implant fixation strength in aged rats.
results_summary: WBV and SIM individually increased bone mass, osseointegration, and push-out force while reducing oxidative stress and inflammation. The combination of WBV and SIM showed superior effects on new bone formation, biomechanical strength, and bone repair gene expression compared to either treatment alone.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats aged 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) on fascicle length, knee joint angle, and function in children with spastic hemiplegic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that WBV combined with physical therapy significantly increased knee extension range of motion, hamstring fascicle length, and functional improvement in children with hemiplegic CP.
population_specificity: Children aged 4-6 years with spastic hemiplegic cerebral palsy.
effective_dosage: WBV was administered 3 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in plasma hypoxanthine (HX) levels after whole-body vibration exercise (WBVE) and their relationships with body composition and muscle-related parameters.
results_summary: WBVE significantly increased plasma HX levels, along with blood ammonia, pyruvic acid, and lactic acid levels. Prior glucose load suppressed the HX increase, and ΔHX showed negative correlations with muscle mass, strength, and quality in the legs under glucose-supplemented conditions.
population_specificity: Eighteen healthy male volunteers.
interactions: Glucose load (75-g oral glucose) administered 30 min prior to WBVE.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of whole-body vibration (WBV) exercises on muscle responses and fall risk in elderly individuals.
results_summary: All selected studies reported positive effects, with WBV exercises improving muscle responses and reducing fall risk in elderly individuals. Methodological quality varied, with four studies rated 'high' and two 'fair,' while risk of bias ranged from low to high.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals

study_goal: To systematically review and meta-analyze the effects of Whole-Body Vibration on glycemic control in patients with Diabetes Mellitus 2.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed a positive and significant effect size (μ ê=0.5731), indicating a substantial difference between groups, though some variability existed. WBV may improve glycemic control in DM 2 patients, but more studies are needed for conclusive results.
population_specificity: Non-insulin dependent Diabetes Mellitus 2 patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of constant versus progressive Whole-Body Vibration Exercise (WBVE) protocols on pain, disability, functional performance, and muscle activity in patients with non-specific chronic low back pain (NSCLBP).
results_summary: Both constant and progressive WBVE protocols significantly reduced pain intensity (64.2% and 61.1%, respectively) and functional disability (48.1% and 53.3%, respectively), while improving functional performance (16.5% and 16.9%, respectively). Electromyography (EMG) showed significant improvements in muscle activity, except for external obliques, with no significant difference between the two protocols.
population_specificity: Thirty-two individuals diagnosed with non-specific chronic low back pain (NSCLBP).
effective_dosage: WBVE sessions for approximately 30 minutes, three times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) training on ankle joint proprioception and balance in stroke patients.
results_summary: WBV significantly improved proprioceptive functions (dorsiflexion-plantar flexion and inversion-eversion) but did not provide additional benefits for balance recovery compared to conventional rehabilitation. Both groups showed significant improvements in balance parameters, but WBV was not superior.
population_specificity: Thirty-five stroke patients.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of WBV training daily using the Trunsan S110 Vibration Training System.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of combining vitamin D with whole-body vibration training (WBVT) for treating osteo-sarcopenia (OS) and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study proposed a protocol to assess WBVT combined with vitamin D for improving bone mineral density, muscle mass, and strength in OS patients, with potential efficacy linked to serum markers like myostatin and irisin. Final results were not provided in the abstract, but the intervention was hypothesized to relieve OS symptoms without adverse effects.
population_specificity: Subjects with osteo-sarcopenia (a combination of sarcopenia and osteoporosis).
study_duration: 1 month of treatment, with follow-ups at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the acute effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) as a conditioning activity on the performance of the mawashi geri kick in karate athletes.
results_summary: WBV significantly reduced the attack phase time of the mawashi geri but did not affect impact force or other kinetic variables. The findings suggest a potential benefit for attack time, though further research is needed to optimize vibration protocols.
population_specificity: Sixteen male karate athletes.
effective_dosage: Four sets of isometric half-squats on a vibration platform at 26 Hz and 4 mm amplitude.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of whole-body vibration (WBV) therapy, electrical stimulation, and transcranial magnetic stimulation on muscle strength, body composition, balance, and functional mobility in patients with muscle dystrophies.
results_summary: The study found that WBV, electrical stimulation, and magnetic stimulation generally had positive outcomes, though results varied based on patients' muscle deficits and disease progression. The abstract suggests further research is needed to determine optimal intervention prescriptions.
population_specificity: Patients with muscle dystrophies

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether post-stroke whole-body vibration (WBV) induces transcriptional reprogramming in the cortex of middle-aged female rats, potentially explaining its neuroprotective effects.
results_summary: WBV therapy significantly altered gene expression in the cortex, with 116 genes upregulated and 258 downregulated, linked to neurogenesis, angiogenesis, excitotoxicity, and cell death. These changes suggest a potential mechanism for WBV's protective effects against stroke consequences.
population_specificity: Middle-aged female Sprague-Dawley rats in constant diestrus (reproductively senescent).
effective_dosage: 15 minutes twice daily for five days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of Whole-Body Vibration on cellular and molecular pathways related to immune and brain functions, with a focus on its therapeutic potential for brain disorders.
results_summary: The study highlights recent evidence suggesting positive effects of WBV on the brain and immune function, emphasizing its potential therapeutic applications for brain disorders. It also discusses the growing understanding of cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying WBV's effects.
population_specificity: Athletes, patients with musculoskeletal disorders, and individuals with brain disorders (broadly referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a 4-week whole-body vibration (WBV) program on trunk endurance and balance in obese female students.
results_summary: Post-treatment, the WBV group showed significantly improved trunk endurance (Sorensen Test, Trunk Flexor Endurance Test) and static balance (Single-Leg Test) compared to the sham group, but worse dynamic balance. WBV demonstrated short-term benefits for trunk endurance and balance in obese females.
population_specificity: Obese female students aged 18-25 with BMI ≥ 30.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of integrating whole-body vibration training (WBVT) into conventional closed kinetic chain exercises for reducing pain and improving function in early knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The WBVT group showed significant improvements in pain reduction (WOMAC pain score) and chair-stand performance (CS-30 score), but no significant difference in physical function (WOMAC physical function score) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 53 patients with early knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grades 1-2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) training in preventing falls and improving physical performance among older adults at risk of falling.
results_summary: WBV training did not prevent falls compared to low-intensity wellness exercises but was associated with improved physical performance (e.g., maintained chair-rising capacity and better short physical performance battery scores) by the end of the follow-up period.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 78.5 years, 75% women) at risk of falling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whole-body vibration therapy (WBVT) in weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing positions on balance and cervical joint position sense in children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: WBVT improved balance and cervical joint position sense in both weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing positions, with the most significant improvements observed when applied simultaneously to both upper and lower extremities in weight-bearing positions.
population_specificity: 60 hemiplegic children with spastic cerebral palsy aged 5-15 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Whole-Body Vibration Therapy (WBVT) combined with functional electrical stimulation (FES) or transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) on lower extremity range of motion, balance, functional mobility, and muscle strength in children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that all three intervention groups (WBVT alone, WBVT+FES, and WBVT+tDCS) showed positive effects, but WBVT combined with tDCS demonstrated the most significant improvements in lower extremity range of motion, functional mobility, dynamic balance, isometric muscle strength, and hand grip strength. The differences between groups were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-15 years with spastic cerebral palsy (42 participants, both genders).
effective_dosage: WBVT was applied four times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) exercise on functional capacity, muscle strength, and health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in severe COPD patients.
results_summary: WBV exercise significantly improved functional capacity (41.36 m increase in 6-minute walk test distance) and showed modest improvements in lower limb muscle strength (57.14% of studies). HRQoL improvements favored WBV but were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze existing WBV protocols and propose a standard operating procedure for WBV training.
results_summary: The study found that WBV protocols vary widely, making efficacy comparisons difficult, and proposed intervention parameters for frequency, amplitude, acceleration, and training mode. No standardized procedure was established.
population_specificity: Different populations (not specified in detail).
effective_dosage: Not standardized (frequency, magnitude, and amplitude intensity data were recorded but not consolidated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whole-body vibration therapy (WBVT) applied to upper extremities, lower extremities, or both in weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing positions on range of motion, balance, and function in children with spastic hemiplegic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: WBVT improved range of motion, hand grip strength, balance, and timed up and go scores across all groups, with the greatest improvements observed in the weight-bearing position for combined upper and lower extremities. The therapy was effective in both weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing positions, but weight-bearing showed superior results.
population_specificity: 60 children aged 5-15 years with spastic hemiplegic cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two WBV frequencies (30 Hz and 45 Hz) on objective physical function outcomes, such as proprioceptive accuracy and balance, in healthy young adults.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in proprioceptive accuracy, quasi-static balance, or dynamic balance among the sham group and the two WBV frequency groups after a 6-week intervention.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults (42 volunteers)
effective_dosage: WBV applied twice a week at 30 Hz (F30) or 45 Hz (F45)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a 36-session Whole-Body Vibration protocol on fall risk, balance, mobility, and heart rate variability in post-COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: WBV training at 2 mm and 4 mm amplitudes reduced fall risk compared to Sham (p = 0.023, effect size 0.530), but no significant changes were observed for balance, mobility, or HRV variables.
population_specificity: 13 patients affected by COVID-19.
effective_dosage: 3 sessions per week on alternate days, totaling 36 sessions.
study_duration: 12 weeks (assuming 3 sessions per week for 36 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether heterodyned whole-body vibration (HWBV) could reduce anxiety associated with opioid use disorder (OUD).
results_summary: HWBV significantly improved daily anxiety scores and HAM-A scores in OUD participants compared to sham treatment, with additional improvements in neuropsychological test performance.
population_specificity: 60 male and 26 female participants diagnosed with OUD undergoing treatment at pain and rehabilitation clinics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of whole-body vibration training (WBVT) for treating stress urinary incontinence (SUI) by examining its effects on urodynamic changes, muscle morphology, and neurotrophic factor expression.
results_summary: WBVT improved bladder leak point pressure/abdominal leak point pressure (BLPP/ALPP) compared to rest, upregulated NT-3/TrkC expression, and enhanced structural morphology of proprioceptors, suggesting it may restore urinary control function in SUI.
population_specificity: Female rats with induced stress urinary incontinence.
effective_dosage: Frequency 30 Hz, amplitude 4 mm, 1 min/repeat, 4 min rest, repeated 10 times, 5 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) in managing type-2 diabetes by comparing its effects on glucose and lipid profiles against other exercises, placebo, or no intervention.
results_summary: WBV was effective in reducing hemoglobin A1C compared to conventional and resistance exercises but showed insignificant effects against stretching, balance exercises, placebo, or no intervention. No significant benefits were found for fasting blood glucose or lipid profiles.
population_specificity: Individuals with type-2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of acute whole-body vibration (WBV) at varying frequencies (5-35 Hz) on heart rate variability and brain excitability in healthy individuals.
results_summary: WBV at 5 Hz decreased brain excitability and parasympathetic activity, while WBV at 20-35 Hz increased brain excitability and sympathetic activity. A strong correlation was found between brain excitability and heart rate variability at 5 Hz.
population_specificity: Thirteen healthy, physically active college students.
effective_dosage: Five bouts of 30 seconds each with 30-second rest intervals, at frequencies of 5, 9, 13, 20, 25, and 35 Hz.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) combined with inspiratory muscle training (IMT) on inflammatory markers, muscle mass, and strength in pre-frail older women.
results_summary: WBV combined with IMT improved inspiratory muscle strength, respiratory thickness, and diaphragmatic mobility, but did not affect BDNF, inflammatory biomarkers, quadriceps thickness, or body composition.
population_specificity: Pre-frail older women aged 60-80 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whole-body vibration (WBV) on inflammatory parameters in non-sarcopenic and sarcopenic elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that an acute session of WBV increased sTNFR2 levels in both non-sarcopenic and sarcopenic groups, with a more pronounced effect in sarcopenic individuals, suggesting WBV may influence inflammatory markers more strongly in those with muscle strength or performance loss.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals, divided into non-sarcopenic (n=22) and sarcopenic (n=22) groups.
effective_dosage: Not specified (acute session of WBV during squat exercise).
study_duration: Acute session (single session with a one-week washout period between protocols).

study_goal: To evaluate the acute effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) on jumping performance measures (jump height, reactive strength index, knee work, and power) in individuals with anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR).
results_summary: The study found that a single bout of WBV did not significantly improve any of the measured jumping performance outcomes (jump height, RSI, knee work, or power) in either limb for individuals with ACLR. The researchers concluded that WBV is likely not effective for acutely improving jumping performance post-ACLR.
population_specificity: Thirty-six individuals with primary, unilateral ACLR.
effective_dosage: Six 60-second bouts of WBV with 2 minutes of rest between bouts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of different whole-body vibration (WBV) interventions on jump height in highly trained karate practitioners.
results_summary: The study found no significant main effect of the intervention on countermovement jump (CMJ) height, but a significant main effect of rest interval, with 4 minutes resulting in higher CMJ values than 2 minutes. The conclusion suggests that a 4-minute rest interval, regardless of intervention type, may enhance jumping performance in trained karate athletes.
population_specificity: Fifteen male karate club athletes (age 20.0 ± 3.8 years).
effective_dosage: WBV at 25 Hz/2 mm and 50 Hz/4 mm, with or without external loads of 30% body weight, performed for 5 sets at 60 s/set.
study_duration: Each intervention was performed for 5 sets with 30 s rest between sets; total duration not specified beyond acute effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Whole-Body Vibration Exercise (WBVE) on pain, disability, balance, proprioception, functional performance, and quality of life in individuals with non-specific chronic low back pain (NSCLBP).
results_summary: The study found that WBVE significantly improved pain, disability, balance, proprioception, and quality of life in NSCLBP patients, with strong statistical significance and clinically meaningful outcomes. The meta-analysis supported these findings with consistent effect sizes across multiple outcome measures.
population_specificity: Individuals with non-specific chronic low back pain (NSCLBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of trunk-oriented exercises versus whole-body vibration on abdominal muscle thickness and balance in children with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
results_summary: Post-treatment results showed significant improvements in abdominal muscle thickness and balance in both groups, but trunk-oriented exercises were more effective than whole-body vibration. Whole-body vibration showed some benefit but was outperformed by the alternative intervention.
population_specificity: 30 boys with DMD, aged 6 to 10 years.
effective_dosage: Whole-body vibration administered three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a six-month interval rehabilitation program, including whole-body vibration (WBV), on motor function in children with PMM2-CDG syndrome.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in motor function, including a mean increase of 5.3 points in GMFM-66, a 19.17-meter improvement in the 1MWT, and enhanced gait analysis metrics after 12 months of WBV intervention.
population_specificity: 13 children with PMM2-CDG syndrome (a congenital disorder of glycosylation).
effective_dosage: Two short inpatient stays (1-2 weeks) combined with a six-month WBV home-training program (specific WBV dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Six-month WBV home-training program with assessments at start, six months, and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of whole-body vibration (WBV) interventions on strength, balance, and mobility in nursing home residents older than 80 years.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that WBV significantly improved lower limb muscle strength, mobility, gait score, balance, and physical performance in older nursing home residents. The study concluded that WBV is an effective intervention for this population.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents older than 80 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic potential of five weeks of whole-body vibration (WBV) on anxiety-like behaviors and cognitive functions in senescent thirty-month-old rats.
results_summary: WBV treatment significantly improved anxiety-like and exploratory behaviors and enhanced discrimination performance in spatial and object memory tests compared to the control group. The effects were comparable to those reported in younger age groups.
population_specificity: Thirty-month-old senescent rats.
effective_dosage: 5 minutes of vibration twice per day, five times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of combining intermittent hypoxia and whole-body vibration training on health-related outcomes in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that intermittent hypoxia and whole-body vibration had a synergistic positive effect on inflammatory markers (CRP and IL-10), bone formation (PINP), and body composition (muscle and bone mass). The combined intervention appeared beneficial for mitigating age-related health deterioration.
population_specificity: Adults over the age of 65.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of whole-body vibration training (WBVT) in stroke patients, focusing on physical function, activities of daily living (ADL), and quality of life (QOL), while exploring moderators influencing outcomes.
results_summary: WBVT significantly reduced spasticity and improved motor and balance functions in stroke patients, but showed no significant effects on gait, ADL, or QOL. Variable frequency and side-alternating vibration were particularly effective, while fixed frequency and vertical vibration were not.
population_specificity: Patients with stroke (991 participants across 25 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate vibration levels in a neonatal transport system and assess the accuracy of a tire-coupled road simulator in replicating real-world vibration conditions.
results_summary: The study found that the tire-coupled road simulator accurately replicated road vibrations, particularly for random profiles, but was less accurate for high-amplitude discrete events like speed humps. The simulator demonstrated high repeatability and matched real-world accelerations well at the patient level.
population_specificity: Newborn infants requiring transport in neonatal intensive care units.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether whole-body vibration (WBV) training positively affects patients with chronic ankle instability (CAI).
results_summary: WBV training significantly improved dynamic balance in posterolateral, posteromedial, and medial directions, with promising results on muscle activity, strength, and proprioception. The meta-analysis included seven studies with 288 participants.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic ankle instability (CAI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of whole-body vibration (WBV) on balance or proprioception in patients with nonspecific chronic low back pain (NSCLBP).
results_summary: Three out of four studies on balance reported significant improvements after WBV, with two being high-quality. All three studies on proprioception also showed significant improvements, though heterogeneity and limited trials prevent definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Patients with nonspecific chronic low back pain (NSCLBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential risks of Whole-Body Vibration Therapy (WBVT) for children with disabilities.
results_summary: The study found that WBVT may pose injury risks for some children but acknowledges its potential therapeutic value. The authors recommend caution and suggest further research.
population_specificity: Children with disabilities

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether discretizing whole-body vibration (WBV) into bouts with short rest intervals enhances osteoporotic bone repair compared to continuous WBV.
results_summary: The study found that repeated bouts of WBV with short rest intervals (rWBV) resulted in more advanced bone repair, higher bone volume fraction, and more uniform mineral distribution by Day 14 compared to sham treatment, while continuous WBV (cWBV) showed intermediate effects. The rWBV group also exhibited a decrease in large-sized angiogenic vessels, whereas the cWBV group showed an increase.
population_specificity: 10-week-old female ovariectomized mice with drill-hole defects in the right tibial diaphysis.
effective_dosage: cWBV: 45 Hz, 0.3 g for 7.5 min/day; rWBV: 3-s bouts at 45 Hz, 0.3 g followed by 9-s rest intervals, repeated for 30 min/day (both delivering 20,250 vibration cycles/day).
study_duration: 5 days/week until euthanasia on Day 7 or 14.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of systemic vibration exercises on various outcomes (balance, muscle strength, spasticity, etc.) in cerebral palsy patients.
results_summary: The study found that systemic vibration was most effective in improving balance and gait, with varying effect sizes across different dependent variables (balance > muscle strength > spasticity, etc.). The intervention showed the highest efficacy in school-age patients and when administered for 7-12 weeks.
population_specificity: Patients with cerebral palsy (infants, school-age children, adolescents, and adults).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of whole-body vibration exercise (WBVE) on body composition in individuals over 60 years of age.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvements in body composition (fat mass, lean mass, or skeletal muscle mass) from WBVE in older adults. The authors concluded that current evidence is insufficient to support WBVE as beneficial for body composition in this population.
population_specificity: Men and women over 60 years of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) combined with conventional physiotherapy on the musculoskeletal system in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in walking performance (speed and step length) and noted positive trends in muscle strength, spasticity reduction, gross motor functions, and overall stability, though these were not statistically significant. The authors concluded that further RCTs are needed to establish clearer evidence for WBV's effectiveness.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (414 patients across 16 studies).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varying durations and intensities mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate acute changes in active plantar flexor muscle stiffness in response to a single bout of whole-body vibration at different frequencies.
results_summary: The study found that 24 Hz WBV increased shear wave speed (SWS) in the medial gastrocnemius at rest and reduced SWS in the soleus during contraction, while subjective stiffness increased after 12 Hz WBV. The results suggest SWS may be useful for assessing acute muscle stiffness changes.
population_specificity: Thirteen healthy adults (37.1 ± 14.4 years old).
effective_dosage: WBV at 6, 12, 24, and 0 Hz (control) for 5 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Whole-Body Vibration Therapy (WBVT) on pain, function, proprioception, and postural stability in patients with subacute and chronic non-specific low back pain (NLBP).
results_summary: WBVT significantly reduced pain in all studies that measured it, improved daily and physical function in most studies, enhanced proprioception in all relevant studies, and showed mixed but generally positive effects on postural stability. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with subacute and chronic non-specific low back pain (NLBP).
effective_dosage: Vibration frequency ranged from 5-30 Hz, administered 2-3 times per week, with some studies including a 2-week break between applications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of whole-body vibration (WBV) exercises, either in isolation or combined with other exercises, on managing cardiovascular diseases (CVDs).
results_summary: The study found that WBV protocols improved hemodynamic, cardiovascular, vascular/arterial, and muscle parameters in individuals with CVD, showing significant acute and chronic responses. It concluded that WBV is a safe and effective training resource for CVD management.
population_specificity: Individuals with cardiovascular diseases (CVDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immediate effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) with deep transverse friction massage and high-power pain threshold ultrasound on treating active myofascial trigger points in the upper trapezius muscle.
results_summary: WBV significantly reduced pain intensity (VAS) more than the other interventions, improved pressure pain threshold (PPT) similarly to other treatments, and increased active contralateral lateral flexion range of motion (CLF ROM) more than deep transverse friction massage.
population_specificity: 66 men with active myofascial trigger points in the upper trapezius muscle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Whole-Body Vibration Therapy (WBVT) has a therapeutic effect on Steroid-Induced Osteonecrosis of the Femoral Head (SIONFH) by examining its impact on osteogenic differentiation and angiogenesis.
results_summary: WBVT improved the ratio of empty lacuna, upregulated Piezo1 expression, and enhanced osteogenic differentiation and angiogenesis markers (BMP2, RUNX2, HIF-1, VEGF, CD31, Emcn) compared to the model group, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for SIONFH.
population_specificity: Adult male and female Sprague-Dawley rats with induced SIONFH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether repeated whole-body vibration (WBV) sessions could increase resting metabolic rate (RMR) in young men.
results_summary: The WBV group showed a significant increase in resting oxygen uptake and RMR after the intervention, while no such changes were observed in the control group, suggesting WBV may enhance metabolic rate and energy expenditure.
population_specificity: 32 healthy young men aged 21-23.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of whole-body vibration on functional mobility, balance, bone mineral density, and muscle power in postburn survivors compared to conventional physiotherapy programs.
results_summary: Whole-body vibration improved functional mobility and balance in postburn survivors but showed no significant differences in bone mineral density or muscle power compared to conventional physiotherapy alone. The evidence was limited, with most studies having a high risk of bias.
population_specificity: Postburn survivors with at least 1% total body surface area affected.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) as a preventative measure against neuronal and behavioral effects of morphine withdrawal in a Wistar rat model.
results_summary: WBV at 80 Hz administered concurrently with morphine over 5 days significantly reduced adaptations in VTA GABA neuronal activity and NAc DA release, modulated DOR expression on NAc CINs, and reduced opioid withdrawal-associated behaviors.
population_specificity: Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of whole-body vibration training (WBVT) combined with KAATSU training on lower limb joint muscle strength in older women.
results_summary: The study found that 16 weeks of WBVT and KAATSU training increased knee extensor strength, with combined intervention showing better improvements in knee extensor, ankle flexor, and extensor strength, as well as hip extension muscle endurance compared to single interventions.
population_specificity: Healthy older women (n = 86, aged not specified).
effective_dosage: WBVT three times per week, about 15 minutes per session; KAATSU training at 150 mmHg.

study_goal: To determine the efficacy of whole-body vibration in treating postnatal constipation in women.
results_summary: Whole-body vibration significantly improved quality of life and constipation severity in postpartum women compared to the control group. The intervention group showed statistically significant improvements (p<0.05).
population_specificity: Postpartum women with complaints of postnatal constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the effect of whole-body vibration training on improving limb function in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Whole-body vibration reduced UPDRSIII scores and improved motor function and walking stability in Parkinson's patients, but its effects on balance ability and daily living ability were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (346 participants, 174 in control group, 172 in observation group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) exposure followed by different activities on physical, cognitive, and sensorimotor systems.
results_summary: WBV exposure followed by sitting or walking degraded reaction speed, while activities involving gaze stabilization exercises (GSE) maintained reaction time. Discomfort was higher after sitting and walking, with no notable balance differences.
population_specificity: Eleven healthy adults.
effective_dosage: Four 1-hour sessions of WBV exposure followed by one of four 5-minute activities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the available scientific evidence on the effects of whole-body vibration on cognitive functions in adults and assess its potential for neurocognitive enhancement.
results_summary: The review suggests that whole-body vibration therapy enhances a wide spectrum of cognitive functions in adults, though insufficient evidence exists to design a standardized protocol for optimal cognitive enhancement.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of whole-body vibration (WBV) on sensorimotor deficits in individuals with chronic ankle instability (CAI) and determine its correlation with brain plasticity.
results_summary: The study found that WBV, combined with balance training, improved sensorimotor function (strength, balance, proprioception, and functional performance) in individuals with CAI, with potential links to brain plasticity changes measured via corticomotor excitability and brain activation.
population_specificity: 80 participants with chronic ankle instability (CAI) recruited from university and local communities.
effective_dosage: 25-38 Hz, 1.3-2 mm amplitude, 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining whole-body vibration (WBV) exercises with traditional physiotherapy improves hamstring-to-quadriceps ratio, walking ability, and postural control in children with hemiparetic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that WBV combined with physiotherapy improved muscle strength, walking performance, and postural control more than physiotherapy alone, though the hamstring-to-quadriceps ratio remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Children with spastic hemiparetic cerebral palsy (gross motor function levels I and II).

study_goal: To determine if adding whole-body vibration (WBV) to pulmonary rehabilitation improves bone strength, lung function, and exercise capacity in elderly COPD patients with osteoporosis.
results_summary: WBV combined with pulmonary rehabilitation significantly improved bone mineral density, bone microstructure, bone metabolism markers, and muscle strength compared to conventional rehabilitation or routine treatment alone. Lung function also improved across all groups, but WBV showed additional benefits for bone and muscle health.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (average age ~65) with stable COPD and osteoporosis.
effective_dosage: WBV was administered three times per week (specific vibration parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if medicine ball wall throws combined with whole-body vibration could improve bat swing performance in collegiate baseball players.
results_summary: The study found that bat speed and exit velocity significantly increased after the intervention, while rotational acceleration and time to contact showed no significant changes. The results suggest that whole-body vibration combined with medicine ball throws can enhance key bat swing performance metrics.
population_specificity: 13 highly trained collegiate baseball players
effective_dosage: 3 sets of 5 medicine ball wall throws at 40 Hz, with 30 seconds rest between sets

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of whole-body vibration training (WBVT) on lower limb muscle strength and physical performance in older adults.
results_summary: WBVT significantly improved knee strength, explosive power, sit-to-stand performance, balance, walking speed, and walking endurance in older adults. The Tinetti total score showed improvement but remains controversial.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 65 years or older)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) on functional recovery, NT-3 expression, and microglia/macrophage reaction after spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: WBV therapy initiated at day 14 post-SCI resulted in the best functional recovery, decreased Iba1 (a microglia/macrophage marker), and the highest increase in NT-3 expression, outperforming passive flexion-extension therapy. The study suggests NT-3 upregulation, particularly in the dorsal horn, may mediate these benefits.
population_specificity: Spinal cord injury (SCI) model (specific species not mentioned in abstract).
study_duration: Intervention initiated at day 14 post-SCI (total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whole-body vibration (WBV) training improves functional capacity and respiratory functions in stroke patients when combined with Neurodevelopmental Treatment (NDT).
results_summary: Both groups (NDT and NDT + WBV) showed significant improvements in walking distance, VO2max, inspiratory capacity, vital capacity, and chest circumference. The NDT + WBV group demonstrated greater increases in walking distance and VO2max compared to NDT alone, but no significant differences were found in respiratory function flow, volume parameters, or chest circumference between groups.
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whole-body vibration training (WBVT) at different frequencies on the balance ability of older adults.
results_summary: The study found that high-frequency WBVT (HF-WBVT) showed the best potential for improving balance in older adults, as indicated by lower Timed Up and Go Test (TUGT) and Five-repetition Sit-to-Stand Test (5STS) values, though not all differences were statistically significant. Low-frequency WBVT (LF-WBVT) also showed statistically significant improvements in TUGT compared to placebo and traditional rehabilitation groups.
population_specificity: Older adults
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequencies categorized as low, medium, and high, but exact values not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize studies on the effects of whole-body vibration (WBV) exercise on wound healing in experimental animal models.
results_summary: The review found beneficial effects of WBV exercise in wound healing, including enhanced angiogenesis, granulation tissue formation, reduced blood glucose levels, improved blood microcirculation, increased myofiber growth, and rapid re-epithelialization. However, none of the included studies fulfilled all methodological criteria, indicating possible biases.
population_specificity: Experimental animal models (mice, rats, or rodents)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) to treadmill running on heart, brain, and behavior in female rats with ISO-induced myocardial damage.
results_summary: WBV and running both reduced hippocampal collagen content and normalized neuroinflammation and BDNF expression in ISO-treated rats, though WBV did not reduce cardiac collagen deposition. WBV was associated with short-term spatial memory improvement, while running had no significant behavioral effects.
population_specificity: 12-month-old female rats with ISO-induced myocardial damage.
effective_dosage: WBV (10 minutes daily), treadmill running (30 minutes daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a gradually increased (7-18 Hz) versus a static (11 Hz) WBV protocol on spasticity, functional strength, balance, and walking ability in children with spastic CP.
results_summary: The 7-18 Hz protocol showed immediate improvements in spasticity, while the 11 Hz protocol demonstrated superior functional improvements after eight weeks, though no significant between-group differences were observed in physical performance. Both protocols improved specific functional measures within their respective groups.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy (mean age: 11.5 ± 2.9 years).
effective_dosage: 30 min/session/day (immediate effects), then four days/week for eight weeks (short-term).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the acute effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) alone and combined with Blood Flow Restriction Training (BFRT) on sprint performance, muscle activation, and metabolic accumulation in male sprinters.
results_summary: WBV and BFRT + WBV significantly improved 0-10m and 0-20m sprint performance, while WBV alone enhanced EMG amplitude in the vastus lateralis and soleus. BFRT + WBV showed similar post-activation enhancement effects to WBV alone, but BFRT alone led to higher metabolic accumulation.
population_specificity: Sixteen male sprinters.
study_duration: Acute effects measured immediately and 15 minutes post-intervention, with 72-hour intervals between interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if six weeks of whole-body vibration could improve balance and reduce fall risk in older adults, and whether these benefits could be sustained two months post-training.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in balance scores or fall rates between the whole-body vibration and control groups, indicating that the intervention was ineffective for improving these outcomes.
population_specificity: Independent living older adults (n=24 initially, n=17 completed).
effective_dosage: Three sessions per week at 20 Hz vibration frequency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Whole-Body Vibration (WBV) on amyloid pathology and neuroinflammation in J20 mice, a model for Alzheimer's disease, and its impact on motor performance.
results_summary: WBV reduced microglia activation in the Dentate Gyrus and restored GFAP-positive astrocyte morphology to wild-type levels in J20 mice, indicating beneficial effects on early brain pathology.
